events.description: The Bank of England left interest rates unchanged but surprised markets with a narrow 5–4 vote to hold.

facts.fact_text: Sterling is on track for its sharpest weekly decline against the dollar since late October.

evidences.evidence_text: Sterling edged back toward $1.36 at the end of a volatile week that nonetheless put sterling on track for its sharpest weekly decline against the dollar since late October

facts.fact_text: The BoE's Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) voted 5-4 to hold interest rates steady.

evidences.evidence_text: On the policy front, the BoE left interest rates unchanged but surprised markets with a narrow 5–4 vote to hold.

facts.fact_text: Four MPC members supported an immediate 25 bp rate cut.

evidences.evidence_text: Four MPC members supported an immediate 25 bp cut, citing expectations that inflation will fall back toward the 2% target from April.

claims.claim_text: Risks from persistent inflation have eased.
claims.author: Bank of England

evidences.evidence_text: The Bank noted that risks from persistent inflation have eased, while downside risks from weaker demand and a softening labor market have become more pronounced.

claims.claim_text: Downside risks from weaker demand and a softening labor market have become more pronounced.
claims.author: Bank of England

evidences.evidence_text: The Bank noted that risks from persistent inflation have eased, while downside risks from weaker demand and a softening labor market have become more pronounced.

evidence.evidence_text: On the policy front, the BoE left interest rates unchanged but surprised markets with a narrow 5–4 vote to hold.
Four MPC members supported an immediate 25 bp cut, citing expectations that inflation will fall back toward the 2% target from April.
The Bank noted that risks from persistent inflation have eased
The Bank noted that risks from persistent inflation have eased, while downside risks from weaker demand and a softening labor market have become more pronounced.
